description: A site just west of Chichester first excavated by Mitchell in 1832. Black suggests that there may have been a temple following a unusual layout of a central room with three connected rooms on either side, the main room had a c. 2m deep pit which showed evidence of burning. Just to the south-west traces of a theatre like structure, to the north-east was a timber palisade, possibly delimiting a temenos, to the west a possible mosaic was found, and to the north was a building witch Mitchell reports contained a coin of Honorius dating to 393 CE to 423 CE.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, et al, (2015), Broadbridge, Bosham (West Sussex), available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449
Rudling, D., (2008), Roman-Period Temples, Shrines and Religion in Sussex, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
Hunter, (1998), An Archaeological Investigation at Broadbridge, Bosham, West Sussex, available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1027493
Black, E., (1985), The Roman Buildings at Bosham, Sussex Archaeological Collections, 123, pg. 255-6
Pitts, (1979), A Gazetteer of the Roman Sites and Finds on the West Sussex Coastal Plain, Sussex Archaeological Collections, 117, pg. 63-83
Mitchell, H., (1866), On the Early Traditions at Bosham, Sussex Archaeological Collections, 11, pg. 127-46
